context: Popper claimed to have recognised already in the <b4_0>1934<b4_0/> version of his <a0_0><b5_0>Logic of Discovery<b5_0/><a0_0/> a fact later stressed by Kuhn, "that scientists necessarily develop their ideas within a definite theoretical framework", and to that extent to have anticipated Kuhn's central point about "normal science". (But Popper criticised what he saw as Kuhn's <a1_0><b6_0>relativism<b6_0/><a1_0/>.) Also, in his collection Conjectures and Refutations: The Growth of Scientific Knowledge (Harper & Row, 1963), Popper writes, "Science must begin with myths, and with the criticism of myths; neither with the collection of observations, nor with the invention of experiments, but with <a2_0><b7_0>the critical discussion of myths<b7_0/><a2_0/>, and of magical techniques and practices. The scientific tradition is distinguished from the pre-scientific tradition in having two layers. Like the latter, it passes on its theories; but it also passes on <a3_0><b8_0>a critical attitude<b8_0/><a3_0/> towards them. The theories are passed on, not as dogmas, but rather with the challenge to discuss them and improve upon them."
